chapter.title: 47 Acinetobacter, Chryseobacterium, Moraxella, Branhamella and Other Nonfermentative Gram-Negative Rods*

sect1.title: 47 Acinetobacter, Chryseobacterium, Moraxella, Branhamella and Other Nonfermentative Gram-Negative Rods*

para.phrase: PIET COOLS, ALEXANDR NEMEC, ANNE-MARIE VAN DEN ABEELE, AND PETER KÄMPFER

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The organisms covered in this chapter belong to a group of taxonomically and phylogenetically diverse, Gram-negative, nonfermentative rods and coccobacilli. Several of the genera discussed belong to the same family, i.e.,Acinetobacter, Moraxella, Oligella, and Psychrobacter belong to the family Moraxellaceae (Gammaproteobacteria) (1) and Balneatrix, Bergeyella, Chryseobacterium, Elizabethkingia, Empedobacter, Myroides, and Sphingobacterium belong to the family Flavobacteriaceae (Bacteroidetes) (2), although their phylogenetic placement in higher taxonomic ranks is still open (3). The genus Weeksella belongs to the family Weeksellaceae (3).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE AGENTS
sect2.para: The species discussed in this chapter all share the common phenotypic features of being catalase positive but failing to acidify the butt of Kligler iron agar (KIA) or triple sugar iron (TSI) agar or of fermentative media, indicating their inability to metabolize carbohydrates by the fermentative pathway. These organisms grow significantly better under aerobic than under anaerobic conditions, and many, i.e., those species that can use only oxygen as the final electron acceptor in the respiratory pathway, fail to grow anaerobically at all.

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Most of the organisms described in this chapter are found in the environment, i.e., soil and water. For methylobacteria, tap water has been implicated as a possible agent of transmission in hospital environments, and methods for monitoring water systems for methylobacteria have been described previously (4). No person-to-person spread has been documented for the species covered in this chapter, except for Acinetobacter species and Branhamella catarrhalis.

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: For almost all species in this chapter, case reports, e.g., of meningitis and endocarditis, can be found, and their clinical importance is mostly restricted to that of opportunistic pathogens. However,Elizabethkingia meningoseptica, Elizabethkingia anophelis, Moraxella lacunata (eye infections), B. catarrhalis (respiratory tract infections), and species of the Acinetobacter calcoaceticus-Acinetobacter baumannii complex are of clinical importance. For some species, scarcity of reported cases can be attributed either to the intrinsic lower virulence of the bacterium or to under-reporting due to isolation and identification difficulties. Broad implementation of proteomic and genomic techniques in clinical laboratories could alter this situation.

A. baumannii ventilator-associated pneumonia and bloodstream infections are known to be associated with a high degree of mortality and morbidity (5). Particular manifestations of A. baumannii are its implication in severely war-wounded soldiers (6) and in victims of natural disasters (7). Although severe infections with A. baumannii have been documented, colonization is much more frequent than infection, and differentiation between these conditions can be difficult. Although uncommon, community-acquired infections with A. baumannii occur. In particular, community-acquired pneumonia with A. baumannii has been reported from tropical areas, such as Southeast Asia and tropical Australia (8–10).

The clinical role ofAcinetobacter pittii and Acinetobacter nosocomialis resembles that of A. baumannii, although, compared to these two species, A. baumannii is more often associated with multidrug resistance and epidemic spread in hospitals and possibly also with higher mortality among patients with systemic infections (9).

OtherAcinetobacter species occasionally associated with human infections are listed in Table 1. A. johnsonii, A. lwoffii, and A. radioresistens seem to be common inhabitants of human skin (11). Several species, A. ursingii in particular, have been found to cause bloodstream infections in hospitalized patients (12–14), while A. junii and A. soli have been implicated in outbreaks of neonatal infections and A. parvus can be isolated from blood cultures (15, 16). Many infections with these species are related to intravascular catheters or have other iatrogenic origins (12, 17); their course is generally benign. For various other Acinetobacter species, although they are occasionally recovered from clinical specimens, a possible role in infection has not been documented.

B. catharrhalis is a human mucosal pathogen, and the molecular mechanisms involved in its metabolism and pathogenesis, including cellular adherence, target cell invasion, and modulation of the host’s immune response, have been reviewed (18). Moraxella species are agents of infections (conjunctivitis, keratitis, meningitis, septicemia, endocarditis, arthritis, and otolaryngologic infections) (19–24). B. catarrhalis has been reported to cause sinusitis, upper respiratory tract infections, and otitis media by contiguous spread of the organisms from a colonizing focus in the respiratory tract (19, 25). However, isolation of B. catarrhalis from the upper respiratory tract (i.e., a throat culture) of children with otitis media or sinusitis does not provide evidence that the isolate is the cause of these infections, because B. catarrhalis is frequently present as a commensal of the upper respiratory tract in children (21, 25). Isolates from sinus aspirates and middle ear specimens obtained by tympanocentesis should be identified and reported.

B. catarrhalis has now been assigned a clear pathogenic role in lower respiratory tract infections (although little is known about its pathogenesis), particularly in adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (26, 27). This conclusion results from observations that B. catarrhalis is not a frequent commensal of the upper respiratory tract in adults (26), and that examination of Gram-stained smears of sputum specimens from patients with exacerbations of bronchitis and pneumonia due to B. catarrhalis usually reveals an abundance of leukocytes, the presence of many Gram-negative diplococci as the exclusive or predominant bacterial cell type, and the presence of intracellular Gram-negative diplococci. Such specimens may yield B. catarrhalis in virtually pure culture, and the organism should be identified and reported. In immunocompromised hosts, B. catarrhalis can cause a variety of severe infections including pneumonia, endocarditis, septicemia, and meningitis (27).

Moraxella species normally exist, similar to B. catarrhalis, as part of the human upper respiratory tract microbiota and rarely cause invasive human disease. M. nonliquefaciens (6, 28) is an unusual organism to be isolated from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and there exists only one case report of M. nonliquefaciens neonatal meningitis. There are only a handful of case reports implicating the organism as a cause of endocarditis, bacteremia, septic arthritis, and endophthalmitis. A fatal endocarditis case caused by M. nonliquefaciens has been reported (29). History of acute sinusitis has been associated with significant depletion in relative abundance of taxa, including Faecalibacterium prausnitzii and Akkermansia spp., and enrichment of Moraxella nonliquefaciens. Enrichment of M. nonliquefaciens was also a characteristic of baseline nasopharyngeal samples of children who subsequently developed acute sinusitis over the 1-year study period (30). These findings were confirmed by profiling of bacterial communities in upper respiratory tracts (31). Identification to the species level based on routine laboratory techniques has been challenging, with final identification often made through 16S rRNA gene sequencing and/or matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) (32). M. osloensis (33, 34) is also part of the normal human upper respiratory tract microbiome. In rare cases, the organism is detected as a pathogen in nonrespiratory clinical samples, mostly in an immunocompromised population. M. osloensis was cultured in blood cultures from bacteremic adults and children (35, 36) and from peritonitis (37) in patients on peritoneal dialysis. Besides M. nonliquefaciens, M. osloensis has been isolated in a wide variety of ocular infections (38), ranging from conjunctivitis and overt keratitis to endophthalmitis. M. lacunata has been associated with infective endocarditis and eye infections (24, 39, 40). M. canis has been isolated from dog bite wounds (41) and debilitated patients (21).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Standard methods for collection, transport, and storage of specimens as detailed inchapters 12 and 18 of this Manual are satisfactory for this group of organisms. The only fastidious species handled in this chapter are Asaia species, Granulibacter bethesdensis, Methylobacterium species, and most Moraxella species; these should be cultured on media containing blood.

sect2.title: DIRECT EXAMINATION
sect2.para: No characteristics can help to recognize the species dealt with in this chapter by means of direct microscopic examination. On Gram stain, organisms appear as Gram-negative rods, coccobacilli, or diplococci. Neither direct antigen tests nor molecular genetic tests to use directly on clinical materials have been developed.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Initial incubation should be at 35 to 37°C, although some strains, among them many of the pink-pigmented species, grow better at or below 30°C and may be detected only on plates left at room temperature. In such cases, all tests should be carried out at room temperature. In fact, some of the commercial kits, such as the API 20NE, are designed to be incubated at 30°C.

Growth on certain selective primary media, e.g., MacConkey agar, is variable and may be influenced by lot-to-lot variations in the composition of media. Gram-negative, nonfermentative bacteria (GNF) that grow on MacConkey agar generally form colorless colonies, although some form lavender or purple colonies due to uptake of crystal violet contained in the agar medium. Selective media have been described forAcinetobacter species (42) and for Moraxella species (43).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Figure 1 provides an overview of identification, in the form of a key to the five large groups that can be distinguished among the species described in this chapter. This key is based only on colony color (pink or not), the presence or absence of oxidase, the production of indole, and benzyl arginine aminopeptidase (trypsin) activity.

Figure 1 refers to Tables 1 through 5, which provide further keys to identify the species of these five groups based on biochemical reactions. Results for enzymatic reactions can be read within hours or up to 2 days of incubation, whereas results of carbon source assimilation tests (Acinetobacter species) and acid production from carbohydrates are read after up to 6 and 7 days, respectively.

For each group of closely related species, we present their taxonomic history (explaining the use of other names in the past and the taxonomic changes introduced since the previous edition), address the clinical importance of the species, and describe the phenotypic data that are useful to differentiate this group from other groups and to differentiate the species within this group. When relevant, antibiotic susceptibility characteristics and treatment options are discussed immediately; otherwise, they are discussed at the end of each section for the five large groups in this chapter.

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Identification of miscellaneous GNF. The organisms covered in this chapter belong to a group of taxonomically diverse, Gram-negative, nonfermentative rods and coccobacilli. They all share the common phenotypic features of failing to acidify the butt of KIA or TSI agar or of oxidative-fermentative media, indicating their inability to metabolize carbohydrates by the fermentative pathway. These characteristics are shared with those of the species of the emended genus Pseudomonas (chapter 43) and those of the species of genera that previously were named as Pseudomonas (chapter 44). G. bethesdensis grows slowly and poorly on SBA. A. parvus forms small colonies as well, but these are already visible after 24 h of incubation.

sect2.para: Although several of the genera discussed in this chapter comprise many more species than the ones addressed here, we focus on those species that can be isolated from clinical samples.

sect1.title: Classical Biochemical Identification Schemes Presented in This Chapter
sect1.para: For all the species in this chapter, except those of the genusAcinetobacter, the biochemical tests listed have been carried out by Georges Wauters according to standardized protocols described in detail in chapter 32 of this Manual. The limited number of tests that have been used to discriminate between the species dealt with in this chapter have been selected because they can be carried out easily and quickly, because they mostly yield uniform results per group or species, and because they are highly discriminatory. For the genus Acinetobacter, data based on standardized physiological and metabolic tests were provided by one of us (see footnotes to Table 1).

sect1.title: Automated, Commercially Available, Phenotypic Identification Systems
sect1.para: Traditional diagnostic systems, e.g., those based on oxidation-fermentation media, aerobic low-peptone media, or buffered single substrates, have now been replaced in many laboratories by commercial kits or automated systems such as VITEK 2 (bioMérieux, Marcy l’Étoile, France) and Phoenix (BD Diagnostic Systems, Sparks, MD) and by the widely used matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). The ability of commercial kits to identify this group of GNF is variable and often results in identification to the genus or group level only, necessitating the use of supplemental biochemical testing for species identification. O’Hara and Miller (44), using the VITEK 2 ID-GNB identification card, reported that of 103 glucose-fermenting and nonfermenting, nonenteric strains, 88 (85.4%) were correctly identified at probability levels ranging from excellent to good and that 10 (9.7%) were correctly identified at a low level of discrimination, for a total of 95.1% accuracy within this group. Bosshard et al. (45) compared 16S rRNA gene sequencing for the identification of clinically relevant isolates of GNF (non-Pseudomonas aeruginosa) with two commercially available identification systems (API 20NE and VITEK 2 fluorescent card; bioMérieux). By 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis, 92% of the isolates were assigned to species level and 8% to genus level. Using API 20NE, 54% of the isolates were assigned to species level, 7% were assigned to genus level, and 39% of the isolates could not be discriminated at any taxonomic level. The respective numbers for VITEK 2 were 53%, 1%, and 46%. Fifteen percent and 43% of the isolates corresponded to species not included in the API 20NE and VITEK 2 databases, respectively. Altogether, commercial identification systems can be useful for identification of organisms commonly found in clinical specimens, like Enterobacteriaceae. However, for rare organisms the performance of these systems can be poor.

sect1.title: Chemotaxonomic Methods
sect1.para: The fatty acid profiles for the most common species of GNF have been published (46).

sect1.title: Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization–Time of Flight Mass Spectrometry
sect1.para: Different commercial platforms for MALDI-TOF MS are available, such as the MALDI BioTyper (Bruker Daltonics) and VITEK MS (bioMérieux), and although the initial cost of mass spectrometry equipment and maintenance costs are relatively high, the additional identification costs per isolate are minimal. MALDI-TOF MS is an established technique for identification of the species covered in this chapter, and most difficulties in obtaining a correct identification are due to missing spectra of newly described species. These problems can be overcome by creating new databases or by adding missing spectra (47, 48).

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Amplification Tests and Sequence-Based Methods
sect1.para: Sanger sequencing-based on rRNA (16S, 16S-23S spacer, or 23S) and housekeeping genes, such as those encoding the RNA polymerase subunit B (rpoB), the gyrase subunit B (gyrB), or the recombination A protein (recA), have become standard techniques to identify bacteria in general (49) and have contributed to the better delineation of several of these groups and the discovery and description of new species. Because these are generally applicable methods, their application for species of this chapter is not outlined in detail. However, for some species multilocus sequence type (MLST) schemes are available (https://pubmlst.org/data/) and also several genomes are available from the EzCloud homepage (50) (http://www.ezbiocloud.net/taxonomy). It is important to note that genome data listed at that homepage are checked by the provider of the EzCloud database with respect to the reliability of the assignment to the given taxa.

Other sequence-based methods, based on DNA array hybridization, have been used for some species of these groups (51). DNA sequence-based fingerprinting methods like amplified ribosomal DNA (rRNA gene) restriction analysis (ARDRA) (52, 53) and tDNA PCR (54, 55) have been applied for the identification of species of several groups as well. These fingerprinting approaches are also generally applicable, but they require reference fingerprint libraries and are often poorly exchangeable between different electrophoresis platforms and laboratories.

Next-generation sequencing (NGS) allows the sequencing of the whole genome of numerous bacteria in a single run. Because the whole genome of isolates is sequenced, a single protocol can be used for many applications such as identification, typing (whole-genome MLST), and detection of resistance and virulence markers. The NGS approach was found to be superior to both MLST and PFGE for the strain typing ofA. baumannii and contributed to the understanding of the transmission dynamics of multidrug-resistant A. baumannii outbreaks (56).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION OF THE FIVE GENOTYPIC GROUPS
Acinetobacter
sect2.para: Members of the genusAcinetobacter are strictly aerobic, oxidase-negative, catalase-positive, coccobacillary bacteria. They are Gram negative but may be difficult to decolorize. Most strains do not reduce nitrate to nitrite in a laboratory test, owing to the lack of a dissimilative nitrate reductase. Tween 80 esterase activity is frequently present, while hemolysis and gelatinase production and oxidation of D-glucose vary. Individual cell sizes are 0.9 to 1.6 μm in diameter and 1.5 to 2.5 μm in length. In the stationary phase, the cells are usually coccoid and occur in pairs. Most strains grow at between 20 and 35°C. Medically relevant species commonly grow well at 37°C, although some of them (Acinetobacter guillouiae and A. johnsonii) show reduced or no in vitro growth at this temperature.

The nameAcinetobacter (from the Greek akineto, “nonmotile”) reflects the fact that these bacteria do not have flagella and, consequently, lack swimming motility. However, twitching motility, a form of surface translocation, on soft agar can occur and some strains can spread rapidly over certain surfaces. Acinetobacters can form a pellicle on the surface of fluid media. They grow well on complex media, including blood agar, nutrient agar, and mostly on MacConkey agar. After 24 h of incubation at 30°C, colonies are 1 to 2 mm in diameter (except for A. parvus, with markedly smaller colonies), colorless to beige, domed, and smooth to mucoid (Fig. 2). Many strains can use a wide variety of organic compounds as single sources of carbon and energy. Selective enrichment can be obtained in mineral media with acetate as the carbon source and ammonium salt as the nitrogen source with shaking incubation at 30°C. General features of Acinetobacter have been reviewed in detail (57, 58).

Members of the genusAcinetobacter are widespread in nature and have been found in soil, water, sewage, and food, as well as in human and animal specimens. Some of the Acinetobacter species have been predominantly cultured from humans (e.g., A. baumannii, A. colistiniresistens, A. nosocomialis, and A. ursingii), while others inhabit diverse ecosystems (e.g., A. calcoaceticus, A. dispersus, A. guillouiae, and A. johnsonii) or are confined to specific niches such as floral nectar (59).

The ecology of most clinically relevantAcinetobacter species is poorly understood. A. baumannii, A. nosocomialis, and A. ursingii have been mainly recovered from clinical specimens in hospitals. Human skin carrier rates of A. baumannii outside hospitals are low (11); higher rates have been found in tropical areas (60). A. baumannii, including multidrug-resistant strains, has been isolated from sick animals (61) and from hospitalized horses (62), but a non-human reservoir has not been found. A. baumannii is, due to its role as a prominent health care-related pathogen, the species for which the epidemiology has been studied most intensively. Epidemic strains of this species can survive in the hospital environment, as they have been found on equipment and on environmental surfaces and materials (63), usually in the vicinity of colonized patients. Multiple sites of the skin and mucosae of patients can be colonized, and colonization may last days to weeks (64).

sect2.title: Species Diversity
sect2.para: In April 2022, the genusAcinetobacter comprised 74 species with correct, validly published names and several provisional taxa (http://www.bacterio.net/acinetobacter.html; apps.szu.cz/anemec/Classification.pdf). A comprehensive review of the genus systematics has now been published (57). Previous studies have shown that nearly all Acinetobacter isolates from colonized or infected patients belong to one of the validly named or provisional species (13, 14, 65). This indicates that the species diversity of acinetobacters found in the human body environment is well covered by the current classification. Twenty-eight validly named species found in human clinical specimens are listed in Table 1.

Recently published core genome-based phylogenies revealed a deep and complex evolution of the genus, with many distant phylogroups and singletons (57, 66). These studies showed that medically relevant Acinetobacter species are not distributed randomly across different lineages but are members of only a few clades. The medically most important clade corresponds to the A. calcoaceticus-A. baumannii complex (67), which includes six species with correct binomial names (Table 1). A. baumannii (69) is clinically and epidemiologically the most significant species of the genus and includes the vast majority of epidemic and multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter strains (7, 68, 69). A comprehensive account of the processes playing a role in A. baumannii pathogenesis has recently been published (70). A. pittii (67) is, along with A. baumannii, the species most frequently isolated from clinical specimens in hospitals in non-epidemic situations (71, 72), predominates in specimens from ambulatory patients (A. Nemec, unpublished), and occurs in soil and water. Less frequently isolated from clinical specimens are A. nosocomialis (67), A. seifertii (73), and A. lactucae (74), which is synonymous with A. dijkshoorniae (75, 76), whereas A. calcoaceticus (77) is primarily a soil organism and is only rarely found in humans (67). The latest addition to the A. calcoaceticus-A. baumannii complex is the valid publication of A. geminorum, proposed for a single clinical strain (78). However, the A. geminorum strain is closely related to (and possibly conspecific with) A. pittii, having whole-genome average nucleotide identity against reference A. pittii strains as high as 95% (57).

The largest well-separated clade of the genus, termed “hemolytic clade” (79), encompasses 14 species with correct binomial names, which nearly all show a strong ability to lyse sheep erythrocytes in ordinary agar media and can display gelatinase activity (57). In contrast, species outside this clade are neither hemolytic nor proteolytic except for a few species with weakly hemolytic strains. Most of the hemolytic clade species have been isolated from humans, and these are marked in Table 1. The clinically most relevant species are A. haemolyticus and A. junii (77). A. colistiniresistens (80) is unique in its intrinsic high-level resistance to polymyxin antibiotics, while A. parvus (81) is the metabolically least active member of the clade, which forms tiny colonies on agar media (Fig. 2) and has the smallest genome of the hemolytic clade species (57).

figure.title: FIGURE 2 Differences in the size of the colonies formed by different Acinetobacter species isolated from human clinical specimens. The strains were grown on TSA (Oxoid) at 30°C for 24 h. (a) A. parvus NIPH 384T; (b) A. ursingii NIPH 137T; (c) A. schindleri NIPH 1034T; (d) A. baumannii ATCC 19606T.

sect2.para: A. lwoffii, A. pseudolwoffii (82), A. schindleri (83), and A. variabilis (84) form another clade, being all catabolically versatile and occurring in humans, animals, and soil and water ecosystems. A. lwoffii is commonly isolated from specimens of ambulatory patients with questionable or no clinical relevance (A. Nemec, unpublished), whereas A. schindleri was associated with health care-related infections (12). The remaining species listed in Table 1 are phylogenetically distant from the aforementioned clades and from each other except for A. bereziniae and A. guillouiae (85), which are ecologically different but phylogenetically related and phenotypically similar; whereas A. bereziniae has been found almost exclusively in humans, A. guillouiae is widely distributed in soil and water ecosystems and only rarely isolated from human specimens (86). The phylogenetically distinct A. ursingii is a clinically important species, being typically involved in health care-related bloodstream infections and associated with the use of intravascular catheters (83, 87).

sect2.title: Species Identification
sect2.para: Identification ofAcinetobacter species by commercial identification systems based on biochemical and physiological properties (e.g., VITEK 2, Phoenix, and API 20NE) is problematic. This stems from the small number of taxonomically relevant characters included in these systems and/or from the insufficient quality of reference data in the identification matrices. A. baumannii and the other species of the A. calcoaceticus-A. baumannii complex are generally not differentiated by these systems, while non-glucose-oxidizing species (e.g., A. ursingii and A. schindleri) can be misidentified (12). The comparison of VITEK 2 and Phoenix for the ability to identify 76 isolates of 16 clinical Acinetobacter species showed that only 19 and 5 isolates were correctly identified by VITEK 2 and Phoenix, respectively (M. Vaneechoutte, unpublished data). In general, routine diagnostic systems such as VITEK 2, Phoenix, or API 20NE are reliable for genus-level allocation but not for identification at the species level.

More reliable phenotypic identification ofAcinetobacter species can be achieved using physiological and metabolic (mainly carbon source assimilation) tests based on the modified system of Bouvet and Grimont (88). Table 1 presents a subset of the system aimed to differentiate species of medical relevance. The data were adopted from the recently published comprehensive overviews of the phenotypes of all known Acinetobacter species (57), which is available in a regularly updated form at apps.szu.cz/anemec/Phenotype.pdf. Assimilation tests were carried out using a basal liquid medium supplemented with 0.1% (wt/vol) carbon source (88). Growth was evaluated after 6 days of culture at 30°C by means of visual comparison between inoculated tubes containing carbon sources and control tubes containing only inoculated basal medium. However, the species of the A. calcoaceticus-A. baumannii complex are not clearly distinguished from each other by this approach. In addition, the need for in-house preparation of most of the tests precludes the use of this scheme in routine diagnostics.

MALDI-TOF MS is currently the most rapid and reliable methodological platform for routine identification ofAcinetobacter species (89). Although the efficacy of diagnostic systems based on MALDI-TOF MS can be hampered by the taxonomic incompleteness of identification databases, this can be addressed by adding the mass spectra of missing species. Notably, the 2020 update of the Bruker Daltonics reference library has been extended to include 59 Acinetobacter species with correct binomial names, including all the species listed in Table 1. Identification accuracy is high especially for strains belonging to taxonomically and phylogenetically well-separated species, e.g., A. johnsonii, A. radioresistens, and A. ursingii (90). Differentiation between closely related species such as those of the A. calcoaceticus-A. baumannii complex or hemolytic clade can be ambiguous, but this is partially solvable by using an alternative MALDI matrix solution (91).

More accurate identification ofAcinetobacter species can be achieved by genotypic methods, especially with those based on sequencing of particular genes. Common targets for this purpose are the rpoB gene (88), so far the best-studied single-gene taxonomic marker for Acinetobacter, or the 16S rRNA gene, although the latter approach suffers from low resolution capacity to differentiate between phylogenetically related species (57). Rapid identification of A. baumannii is possible using PCR detection of the blaOXA-51-like gene, which is intrinsic to this species (92), even though in extremely rare strains this approach can be complicated by insertions of mobile elements in the gene or the presence of blaOXA-51-like genes on plasmids in non-A. baumannii strains.

The most precise identification is achievable via genome-wide comparative analysis. This is facilitated by the public availability of genome sequences for the type strains of all validly named species (57) (apps.szu.cz/anemec/Genomes.pdf) and websites that enable the determination of genome-based taxonomic parameters such as average nucleotide identity (http://jspecies.ribohost.com/jspeciesws) or digital DNA–DNA hybridization (http://ggdc.dsmz.de). It is of practical and economical value that draft genomes with approximately only 20% coverage render stable average nucleotide identity values when compared with complete genomes.

sect2.title: Genotyping and Epidemiology
sect2.para: A number of molecular methods have been described for differentiation between isolates of the same species and for the study of the epidemiology of acinetobacters, in particular that ofA. baumannii. Of these, macrorestriction analysis with pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (93) has historically been a useful method, although its resolution can be hampered by the concurrent occurrence of genotypically closely related but epidemiologically distinct strains. Improved resolution can be achieved by typing based on the variable number of tandem repeats (94) or CRISPR-based subtyping (95). Sequence analysis of the blaOXA-51-like gene has been proposed as another useful typing method, based on the correlation between particular blaOXA-51-like enzymes and epidemic clones of A. baumannii (96). With the growing availability of whole-genome sequencing, a number of studies focused on their use for analysis of hospital outbreaks. Genome-wide analysis has been shown to be superior to conventional typing techniques at the levels of species identification, population structure analysis, and intrahospital outbreak investigation (97, 98).

Multilocus sequence typing (MLST) remains the standard for global and long-term epidemiological and population studies. Two MLST schemes, proposed by Bartual et al. (99) and Diancourt et al. (100) (https://pubmlst.org/abaumannii), are currently used for A. baumannii. Both schemes are based on the internal fragments of seven housekeeping genes, and they share three genes. The two schemes yield compatible results, although a higher resolution has been reported for the former (101). A MLST scheme based on the core genome (cgMLST) has been proposed for A. baumannii by Higgins et al. (102). The scheme is highly discriminatory and can identify separate outbreaks caused by A. baumannii strains belonging to the same conventional MLST type (103).

Resistance to multiple antimicrobials and the occurrence of hospital outbreaks have been associated with several international lineages ofA. baumannii, particularly with the so-called European (also termed international or global) clones I and II (100, 104, 105). The earliest known strain of clone I was isolated in 1977 (106), and this lineage prevailed among outbreak and multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter strains in some European countries in the 1980s and 1990s (107). Currently, strains belonging to or related to clone II dominate in the global population of multidrug-resistant A. baumannii, although clone I and other lineages can be common or even prevail in some regions (101, 108–112). Allocation of isolates to international lineages or the identification of novel clones can be achieved by both MLST schemes. Clones I and II correspond, respectively, to MLST-based clonal complexes CC1 and CC2 in the scheme of Diancourt et al. (100) and to CC109 and CC92 in that of Bartual et al. (99), according to Karah et al. (101).

sect2.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect2.para: A. baumannii has an extraordinary capacity to acquire or develop resistance to all antibiotics used in the treatment of Acinetobacter infections (68, 104). With the growing proportion of A. baumannii strains resistant to carbapenems, a last therapeutic option is disappearing, although these strains often remain susceptible to colistin and/or tigecycline. Even though multidrug resistance is mainly confined to A. baumannii, strains of other clinically relevant species, such as A. pittii, A. nosocomialis, and A. ursingii, and A. bereziniae can also be resistant to multiple antibiotics, including carbapenems (113–116). Resistance mechanisms in A. baumannii comprise all general strategies, including enzymatic breakdown, modification of target sites, active efflux, and decreased influx of antibiotics. The known resistance mechanisms have been reviewed previously (69). Recent genomic studies have also shed light on the genetic organization of resistance determinants in multidrug-resistant A. baumannii. Large clusters of horizontally transferred genes, conferring resistance to multiple antibiotics and interspersed with mobile genetic elements (resistance islands), were found to be integrated at a specific genomic site in a number of strains (107). Despite the high intraclonal variability of the resistance islands, these structures seem to have evolved independently in the two main A. baumannii clones (117, 118).

In vitro determination of antimicrobial susceptibility can be achieved by disk diffusion, agar dilution, broth microdilution, or Etest. The panel of tested antibiotics should cover the spectrum of agents with potential activity against A. baumannii, including third- or fourth-generation cephalosporins, sulbactam, antipseudomonal penicillins combined with β-lactamase inhibitors, carbapenems, aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, polymyxins, and tetracyclines (119). Of note, susceptibility to colistin should not be tested by disk diffusion due to poor diffusion of this compound in agar. Etest and broth microdilution for determination of the MIC for this drug have been compared and showed a good concordance in the MIC range of 0.25 to 1 mg/liter (120).

sect2.title: Granulibacter bethesdensis
sect2.para: G. bethesdensis (Acetobacteraceae, Alphaproteobacteria) (121) is a Gram-negative, strictly aerobic, coccobacillary to rod-shaped bacterium, the only species of a sublineage within the acetic acid bacteria in the family Acetobacteraceae. This fastidious organism grows poorly and slowly on sheep blood agar (SBA) at an optimum temperature of 35 to 37°C and an optimum pH of 5.0 to 6.5. It produces a yellow pigment, oxidizes lactate (and, weakly, acetate) to carbon dioxide and water, acidifies ethanol, and can use methanol as a sole carbon source, all characteristics that distinguish it from other acetic acid bacteria. The DNA base composition is 59.1 mol% G+C. It was isolated first from three patients with chronic granulomatous disease (121) and more recently from additional patients with the same disease, including cases leading to fatal meningitis (122) or fulminant sepsis (123). The serological reactivity (124) and the molecular mechanisms (124, 125) have been studied in detail.

sect2.title: Haematobacter
sect2.para: ThreeHaematobacter species (Rhodobacteraceae, Alphaproteobacteria) have been described, i.e., H. massiliensis (formerly Rhodobacter massiliensis), H. missouriensis, and Haematobacter genomic species 1 (Table 2) (126). The genus description is based on data of 12 strains received at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), isolated from patients with septicemia. From 2007 on, only one aortic valve endocarditis caused by a Haematobacter-like organism and one mitral valve endocarditis caused by H. massiliensis have been reported (127, 128).

Cells grow after 2 to 5 days on blood and chocolate agar as nonhemolytic, convex, smooth to mucoid, glistening colonies. On Gram stain, organisms appear predominantly as long serpentine Gram-negative rods with filaments. The species cannot easily be differentiated phenotypically, and even the 16S rRNA gene sequences are closely related.Haematobacter species were described as asaccharolytic, but when low-peptone phenol red agar is used (see chapter 32), H. missouriensis is clearly saccharolytic, producing acid from glucose and xylose and sometimes from mannitol, whereas H. massiliensis strains do not acidify carbohydrates. Acid is produced from ethylene glycol by all species. All the species are strongly urease and phenylalanine deaminase positive. Arginine dihydrolase is also positive but sometimes delayed. Asaccharolytic Haematobacter strains resemble Psychrobacter phenylpyruvicus but can be differentiated by the lack of tributyrine esterase, the lack of growth improvement by Tween 80, and the presence of arginine dihydrolase. Differences from Psychrobacter faecalis, Psychrobacter pulmonis, and related species are the lack of tributyrine and Tween 80 esterase, the lack of nitrate reductase, and a positive arginine dihydrolase test.
Haematobacter strains have low MICs for amoxicillin, fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides, and carbapenems but variable MICs for cephalosporins, monobactams, and piperacillin.

sect2.title: Moraxella/Branhamella
sect2.para: The genusMoraxella comprises ~20 species that have been validly named. The genus Branhamella comprises a single species, B. catarrhalis, of which Moraxella catarrhalis is a homotypic synonym. B. catarrhalis, M. osloensis, M. nonliquefaciens, and M. lincolnii are part of the normal microbiota of the human upper respiratory tract. Animal species include M. bovis, isolated from healthy cattle and other animals, including horses; M. boevrei and M. caprae (goats); M. canis (dogs, cats, and camels); M. caviae (guinea pigs); M. cuniculi (rabbits); M. ovis and M. oblonga (sheep); and M. plurianimalum and M. porcinum (pigs and sheep) (129).

B. catarrhalis and M. canis grow well on SBA and even on tryptic soy agar (TSA), and their colonies may reach >1 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation. Colonies of B. catarrhalis grow well on both blood and chocolate agars, and some strains also grow well on modified Thayer-Martin and other selective media. Colonies are generally gray to white, opaque, and smooth and measure about 1 to 3 mm after 24 h of incubation. Characteristically, the colonies are very consistent and may be nudged intact across the plate with a bacteriological loop like a “hockey puck” and can be removed from the agar entirely. Most M. canis colonies resemble those of the Enterobacteriaceae (large, smooth colonies) and may produce a brown pigment when grown on starch-containing Mueller-Hinton agar (41). Some strains may also produce very slimy colonies resembling colonies of Klebsiella pneumoniae (41). M. nonliquefaciens forms smooth, translucent to semiopaque colonies 0.1 to 0.5 mm in diameter after 24 h and 1 mm in diameter after 48 h of growth on SBA plates. Occasionally, these colonies spread and pit the agar. Colony morphologies of M. lincolnii (130), M. osloensis, and Psychrobacter phenylpyruvicus (formerly Moraxella phenylpyruvica) are similar, but pitting is rare. On the other hand, pitting is common with M. lacunata, whose colonies are smaller and form dark haloes on chocolate agar. Rod-shaped Moraxella species, especially M. atlantae and M. lincolnii, are more fastidious and display smaller colonies on SBA, <1 mm in diameter after 24 h. Colonies of M. atlantae are small (usually 0.5 mm in diameter) and show pitting and spreading. The growth of M. atlantae is stimulated by bile salts, which explains its growth on MacConkey agar. M. nonliquefaciens and M. osloensis produce colonies that are somewhat larger than those of M. atlantae and that are rarely pitting. Colonies of M. nonliquefaciens may be mucoid. A selective medium, acetazolamide agar, inhibiting growth of neisseriae when incubated in ambient atmosphere, has been described for B. catarrhalis (43) and can be used for other Moraxella species as well.

Moraxella species are coccoid or coccobacillary organisms (plump rods), occurring predominantly in pairs and sometimes in short chains, that tend to resist decolorization in the Gram stain (131). M. canis and B. catarrhalis are Neisseria-like diplococci, and they can easily be distinguished from other moraxellae or other coccoid species by performing a Gram stain on cells cultured in the vicinity of a penicillin disk: cells of M. canis and B. catarrhalis remain spherical diplococci of 0.5 to 1.5 μm in diameter, although of irregular size, whereas coccobacilli show obviously rod-shaped and filamentous cells.

Moraxella species and B. catarrhalis are asaccharolytic and strongly oxidase positive. B. catarrhalis and M. canis are also strongly catalase positive, and most strains reduce nitrate and nitrite. B. catarrhalis and M. canis may be easily distinguished from the commensal Neisseria species, which are also frequently isolated from respiratory clinical specimens, by the ability of the former to produce DNase and butyrate esterase (tributyrine test). Rapid butyrate esterase tests have been described (132), and the indoxyl-butyrate hydrolysis spot test is commercially available (Remel, Inc., Lenexa, KS). Butyrate esterase is, however, also present in some other Moraxella species. M. canis acidifies ethylene glycol and alkalinizes acetate, in contrast to B. catarrhalis. There are few biochemical differences between B. catarrhalis and M. nonliquefaciens, which are differentiated from each other mainly on the basis of morphological characteristics and by nitrite reductase and DNase activity of B. catarrhalis.

M. atlantae is the only Moraxella species to be positive for pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase (133). M. lacunata is the only proteolytic species with gelatinase activity. Using the plate method (see chapter 32), gelatin hydrolysis occurs usually within 2 to 4 days. A more rapid and almost equally specific test to differentiate M. lacunata from other moraxellae is the detection of Tween 80 esterase activity, which is often positive within 2 days, whereas all other species, except for very rare M. osloensis strains, remain negative. This species should also be distinguished from Psychrobacter species, which are also Tween 80 esterase positive, but P. phenylpyruvicus and P. sanguinis are urease positive and other Psychrobacter species exhibit luxuriant growth on plain agar, like TSA, even at 25°C.
M. lincolnii is biochemically quite inactive.

M. osloensis alkalinizes acetate, acidifies ethylene glycol, and is resistant to desferrioxamine (250-μg disk). M. nonliquefaciens has opposite properties to those of M. osloensis and is, in addition, always nitrate reductase positive.

MostMoraxella species are susceptible to penicillin and its derivatives, cephalosporins, tetracyclines, quinolones, and aminoglycosides (134, 135). Production of β-lactamase has been only rarely reported for Moraxella species; for B. catarrhalis, >95% of the isolates produce an inducible, cell-associated β-lactamase (43, 136). Isolates of B. catarrhalis are generally susceptible to amoxicillin-clavulanate, expanded-spectrum and broad-spectrum cephalosporins (i.e., cefuroxime, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefpodoxime, ceftibuten, and the oral agents cefixime and cefaclor), macrolides (e.g., azithromycin, clarithromycin, and erythromycin), tetracyclines, rifampin, and fluoroquinolones. However, macrolide-resistant B. catarrhalis isolates have been reported (137, 138).

sect2.title: Oligella
sect2.para: The genusOligella comprises two species, O. ureolytica (formerly CDC group IVe) and O. urethralis (formerly Moraxella urethralis and CDC group M-4) (139). Both species have been mainly isolated from the human genitourinary tract as a commensal organism. However, case reports in patients with underlying immunosuppressive conditions have been described. Most of these infections take place in the urinary tract (140). Extra-genitourinary infections with isolates from blood, lymph nodes, and protected bronchial samples have been reported (141–146).

Colonies ofO. urethralis are smaller than those of M. osloensis and are opaque to whitish. Colonies of O. ureolytica are slow growing on blood agar, appearing as pinpoint colonies after 24 h but large colonies after 3 days of incubation. Colonies are white and opaque, with entire borders, and are nonhemolytic.

O. ureolytica and O. urethralis are small, asaccharolytic coccobacilli that rapidly acidify ethylene glycol and are susceptible to desferrioxamine. Most strains of O. ureolytica are motile by peritrichous flagella, and all are strongly urease positive (with the urease reaction often turning positive within minutes after inoculation) and reduce nitrate. O. urethralis strains are nonmotile and urease and nitrate reductase negative, but they reduce nitrite and are weakly phenylalanine deaminase positive. Bordetella bronchiseptica and Cupriavidus pauculus are also rapidly urease positive but are desferrioxamine resistant.

O. urethralis and M. osloensis have biochemical similarities, e.g., accumulation of poly-β-hydroxybutyric acid and failure to hydrolyze urea, but can be differentiated on the basis of nitrite reduction and alkalinization of formate, itaconate, proline, and threonine, all positive for O. urethralis (147). Moreover, O. urethralis is susceptible to desferrioxamine, and tributyrate esterase is negative, in contrast to M. osloensis.
MALDI-TOF MS offers reliable genus identification and species differentiation (148–150).

O. urethralis strains are generally susceptible to most antibiotics, including penicillin, aminoglycosides, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, but production of penicillinases and cephalosporinases has been observed. Acquired resistance to fluoroquinolones is frequently noted. O. ureolytica strains are generally resistant to ampicillin, chloramphenicol, erythromycin, penicillin G, tetracycline, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (151, 152).

sect2.title: Paracoccus
sect2.para: The genusParacoccus (Rhodobacteraceae, Alphaproteobacteria) includes >95 validly named species. Originally, P. yeei seemed unique in the genus, presenting as an environmental opportunistic pathogen of clinical importance. The bacterium has been isolated from human wound infections (153), endophtalmitis, and keratitis. Case reports of bloodstream infections with bacteremia, but without serious clinical sepsis, and peritonitis related to peritoneal dialysis have been described (154, 155).

P. yeei organisms are coccoid cells, showing many diplococci and a few very short rods. The O-shaped or doughnut-shaped cells (Fig. 3) upon Gram stain examination, due to the presence of vacuolated or peripherally stained cells, are highly characteristic. Colonies on blood agar are large and mucoid with a pale yellow pigmentation. The species is saccharolytic and urease positive. Antibiotic susceptibility testing to a broad range of antibiotic classes showed no specific resistant phenotypes.

figure.title: FIGURE 3 Gram stain of P. yeei, showing characteristic doughnut-shaped morphology.

sect2.para: In 2015, four strains isolated from blood of four unrelated patients were assigned to a novel species within the genus and namedParacoccus sanguinis (156). Organisms present as Gram-negative rods in pairs or chains. Colonies on chocolate and SBA are pale yellow, moist, circular, and convex. Acid production from most carbohydrates is absent. Recently, P. sanguinis was isolated from the blood of a premature newborn with breathing difficulties and an abnormal chest X-ray (157). MALDI-TOF MS was not able to identify the isolate, but 16S rRNA gene sequencing showed high similarity with the type strain. However, the pathogenic potential of this species needs further confirmation.

sect2.title: Psychrobacter
sect2.para: The genusPsychrobacter comprises >50 species, of which most belong to the marine and Antarctic environment or are isolated from poikilothermic animals. Only a subset of Psychrobacter spp. are considered medically relevant opportunistic pathogens. A limited number of published case reports describe a variety of clinical manifestations that include bacteremia, meningitis, surgical wound infections, and ocular infections. Apart from Psychrobacter phenylpyruvicus (formerly M. phenylpyruvica), the Psychrobacter strains isolated from clinical material were considered until recently as belonging to the species Psychrobacter immobilis, originally isolated from poultry. In 2012 (157), it was shown that almost all the strains formerly identified as P. immobilis belong in fact to the species P. faecalis and P. pulmonis, isolated first from pigeons and lambs, respectively (158, 159). P. immobilis is rarely, if at all, isolated from humans.

P. faecalis and P. pulmonis are coccoid Gram-negative rods growing on TSA with large, creamy colonies. P. faecalis is saccharolytic and acidifies glucose and xylose, while P. pulmonis is asaccharolytic. Both species produce acid from ethylene glycol. They are Tween 80 esterase, tributyrate esterase, and nitrate reductase positive and, unlike the type strain of P. immobilis, urease negative and nitrite reductase positive. Colonies may resemble those of Haematobacter, but the latter lack nitrate reductase, Tween 80 esterase, and tributyrin esterase and are strongly urease positive, arginine dihydrolase positive, and phenylalanine deaminase positive.

P. phenylpyruvicus and P. sanguinis are phenotypically very similar, although genetically clearly distinct. P. sanguinis (160, 161) seems to occur more frequently in clinical samples than P. phenylpyruvicus and has been isolated from blood and cases of meningitis (160–163). The majority of older P. phenylpyruvicus collection strains are in fact P. sanguinis. A salient feature is the dramatic effect of Tween 80 in promoting growth of both species, resulting in colonies 2 to 3 times larger on Tween 80 agar compared to blood agar. Since these species grow very poorly or not at all on usual media, like TSA, supplementation with 0.1% Tween 80 is recommended when blood agar cannot be used, as for susceptibility testing to desferrioxamine or for testing growth abilities in broth at different temperatures.

P. phenylpyruvicus grows in 12% NaCl tryptic soy broth supplemented with 0.1% Tween 80, while P. sanguinis does not. Phenylalanine deaminase is always positive in P. phenylpyruvicus but only in one-third of P. sanguinis strains.

In 2017,Psychrobacter piechaudii, a new species with human pathogenic potential within the genus, was described, based on data of four human strains (164). Cells are Gram-negative coccobacilli arranged in pairs, with some cells resistant to decolorization. Small, convex, translucent, nonhemolytic, nonpigmented colonies on SBA and pinpoint colony morphology with pitting on chocolate agar are observed. Growth occurs at 0 to 37°C, with up to 10% NaCl tolerance for most strains. Cells are not able to reduce nitrate to nitrite, Tween 80 esterase is present, and urease activity varies. P. sanguinis and P. phenylpyruvicus are among the closest phylogenetic relatives. In 2021 (165), in a premature infant with hydrocephalus and multiple cerebrospinal fuid (CSF) shunt operations, P. piechaudii health care-related ventriculo-meningitis was described. MALDI-TOF MS only produced reliable results to genus specification; sequencing of the full 16S rRNA gene achieved species identification.
MostPsychrobacter species are resistant to penicillin but susceptible to most other antibiotics (166).

sect2.title: Wohlfahrtiimonas chitiniclastica
sect2.para: The genusWohlfahrtiimonas comprises three species. W. chitiniclastica and Wohlfahrtiimonas larvae were isolated from larvae of different fly vectors in tropical, subtropical, and moderate climates. Wohlfahrtiimonas populi, from the diseased bark of the Populus tree, has no documented human pathogenic potential. W. chitiniclastica was decribed in 2008 and is closely related to the “Gilardi rod group 1” also isolated from wounds and blood (167, 168). The type strain of W. chitiniclastica was originally classified as “Gilardi rod group 1.”

W. chitiniclastica and W. larvae may be associated with human accidental myiasis. In these cases of wound infections, cellulitis, and osteomyelitis, other microbial species are frequently detected along with Wohlfahrtiimonas, making it difficult to estimate the intrinsic pathogenic potential of the bacterium. However, as well as polymicrobial bacteremia or sepsis (167, 169), several case reports of monomicrobial W. chitiniclastica bacteremia and clinical sepsis have been described (170–172).

The organisms are short, coccoid rods, growing on current selective and nonselective media with flat, slightly spreading colonies. Some carbohydrates, like glucose, xylose, and fructose, are weakly and slowly acidified.W. chitiniclastica exhibits a very strong phenylalanine deaminase reaction, and a strong chitinase activity is present. Wohlfahrtiimonas spp. are resistant to penicillin and susceptible to broad-spectrum β-lactam penicllins, cephalosporins, carbapenems, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, and quinolones (173).

sect2.title: Ignatzschineria
sect2.para: The genusIgnatzschineria, first described in 2001, now comprises several species with animal or human pathogenic potential. WGS analysis suggests that Ignatzschineria larvae and Ignatzschineria ureiclastica are strongly related or identical (sub)species within the genus (174). Both bacteria exhibit a strong chitinase activity, as in W. chitiniclastica, which is, however, urease negative. Ignatzschineria indica forms a separate species within the genus. Ignatzschineria spp. are accidental zoonotic pathogens, carried by fly larvae. They have been isolated from maggot-infested wounds and abscesses, in some cases with concomitant bacteremia (175, 176). The organisms are short, straight rods that grow on blood agar and MacConkey agar after 1 to 2 days as small, convex, nonpigmented, and translucent colonies. Automated biochemical instruments and MALDI-TOF MS may produce no identification or an incorrect identification. Genotypic methods, 16S rRNA gene sequencing, and WGS are required to achieve genus and species identification, respectively. Antibiotic susceptibility profiles may vary between species, but overall susceptibility to β-lactam antibiotics is conserved.

sect2.title: Alishewanella
sect2.para: The genusAlishewanella harbors seven species. Cells are Gram-negative, motile or nonmotile rods, oxidase and catalase positive, and negative for arginine dihydrolase and indole (177). Alishewanella has been identified as part of the blood microbiome in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (177). Alishewanella fetalis has been isolated from a clinical sample, i.e., from a human fetus at autopsy, but its association with clinical infection is unknown (178).

A. fetalis (Table 3) grows at temperatures between 25 and 41°C, with optimum growth at 37°C. A. fetalis can withstand NaCl concentrations of up to 8% but not 10%, which helps to differentiate this species from Shewanella algae, which can grow in 10% NaCl (178). Also, in contrast to Shewanella species, it does not produce H2S in the butt of TSI and KIA. The type strain, tested by Georges Wauters, acidifies glucose and does not hydrolyze esculin.

sect2.title: Inquilinus limosus
sect2.para: I. limosus, one of the two species in the genus Inquilinus, is a rod-shaped, Gram-negative bacterium that measures 1.5 to 2 μm in width by 3.5 μm in length and grows at 35 and 41°C but poorly at 25°C. Colonies are nonpigmented and very mucoid and grow on ordinary media such as TSA. Some strains are motile by one or two polar flagella, but motility is difficult to demonstrate due to the mucoid character of the colonies. In contrast to the original description (179), the species is saccharolytic, acidifying glucose, mannitol, xylose, and other carbohydrates. In contrast, ethylene glycol is not acidified. β-Galactosidase, pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase, and trypsin are positive, but alkaline phosphatase is negative. Esculin is hydrolyzed. All strains are positive for catalase, β-glucosidase, proline aminopeptidase, and pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase and negative for lysine, arginine, ornithine, denitrification, and indole production (179).

I. limosus can be distinguished from Sphingobacterium species by its lack of alkaline phosphatase activity and by its acidification of mannitol. Sphingobacterium spiritivorum also produces acid from mannitol but acidifies ethylene glycol, unlike Inquilinus. I. limosus differs from Rhizobium radiobacter and Pannonibacter phragmitetus by the absence of acid production from ethylene glycol (positive in most of the P. phragmitetus strains) and by the lack of nitrate reductase activity.

Identifying this species can be challenging because it is not contained in the databases of commercial identification kits such as API 20NE and its mucoid appearance may lead to confusion with mucoidP. aeruginosa strains (180). However, MALDI-TOF MS appears to identify the species correctly (181, 182). Isolates can be recovered on colistin-containing Burkholderia cepacia selective media but are inhibited on B. cepacia selective agar, which also contains gentamicin (183).

All isolates are reported to be resistant to penicillins and cephalosporins, kanamycin, tobramycin, colistin, doxycycline, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and susceptible to imipenem, gentamicin, and ciprofloxacin (180, 183).

I. limosus has been isolated from soil samples and from respiratory secretions of cystic fibrosis patients (180, 181, 184–187). The clinical impact of chronic colonization with I. limosus remains unclear. Chiron et al. (183) reported that for one patient, I. limosus was the only potential pathogen recovered from the sputum, and acquisition of this bacterium was followed by a worsening of the patient’s lung function. Lenhart and coworkers reported that lung function and nutrition status at time of detection, lung function decline, and pulmonary exacerbation rates in Inquilinus cases were similar to those in patients with chronic P. aeruginosa infection (188).

sect2.title: Myroides odoratimimus and Myroides odoratus
sect2.para: The genusMyroides includes 16 species. Myroides odoratimimus (189), Myroides odoratus (formerly Flavobacterium odoratum (190), and Myroides injenensis have been isolated from clinical samples and have some clinical importance. Cells are thin, middle-sized (0.5 μm in diameter and 1 to 2 μm long), nonmotile rods, and both species display a gliding motility. The spreading colonies develop a typical fruity smell, similar to the odor of Alcaligenes faecalis. The yellow pigment, although less pronounced than that of some Chryseobacterium species, is of the flexirubin type.

Myroides species grow on most media, including MacConkey agar. Growth occurs at 18 to 37°C, but usually not at 41°C. Myroides species are asaccharolytic, urease positive, and nitrate reductase negative, but nitrite is reduced. M. odoratus can be differentiated by its susceptibility to desferrioxamine, while M. odoratimimus is resistant. The species also differ by their cellular fatty acid patterns, with M. odoratimimus having significant amounts of C13:0i and C15:0 (189). MALDI-TOF MS, but not VITEK 2, has been shown to efficiently distinguish between M. odoratimimus and M. odoratus (190).

M. odoratus has been reported mostly from urine but has also been found in wounds, sputum, blood, and ear specimens and identified as causes of septic shock, pericardial effusion, necrotizing fasciitis, and cellulitis (191–195). M. odoratimimus has been described in case reports of fulminant erysipelas and sepsis, in health care-related outbreaks of urinary tract infection, in a soft tissue infection following a pig bite, in health care-related catheter-related infections, and in empyema in a patient with liver abscess (196–203). Myroides bacteremia has been reported in 48 cases in the U.S (204). Most strains are resistant to penicillins, cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, aztreonam, and carbapenems (192, 205). A genomic analysis of a multidrug-resistant strain has been reported (206).

M. injenensis was isolated from a patient admitted to the emergency room with fever and abruptly reduced drainage from the left kidney (207) and showed a high level of resistance to multiple antibiotic agents (208). M. injenensis was also reported in a case of bacteremia and severe cellulitis in a patient with cirrhosis (209).

sect2.title: Ochrobactrum anthropi and Ochrobactrum intermedium
sect2.para: Ochrobactrum, Pseudochrobactrum, Rhizobium, and Pannonibacter have many morphological and biochemical characteristics in common, and therefore additional characteristics for these taxa are provided in Table 3.

In 2020 it was proposed to reassign members of theOchrobactrum genus to the Brucella genus. Moreno and colleagues (210) opposed the unification of Brucella and Ochrobactrum due to the differences in epidemiology, pathogenicity, virulence, diagnosis, and treatment between the two genera. For this reason, the editors of this Manual prefer to maintain the separation of these organisms into two groups. The Ochrobactrum species are discussed in this chapter. The reader is referred to chapter 51, “Brucella,” for additional discussion.

The genusOchrobactrum comprises at present 19 species. Two species, i.e., O. anthropi (211) and O. intermedium (212), are currently isolated from humans. O. haematophilum (213), O. pseudogrignonense (213), and O. pseudintermedium (214) have been recovered from clinical samples. O. anthropi (211) comprises the so-called urease-positive Achromobacter species, formerly designated CDC group Vd (biotypes 1 and 2), and Achromobacter groups A, C, and D.

Colonies on SBA are small, ~1 mm after overnight incubation, but grow large and creamy after 2 days and appear smooth, circular, and clearly delineated.Ochrobactrum species are Gram-negative rods, approximately 0.6–1.2 to 2 μm in length, and motile by peritrichous flagella, although most cells have only one or two very long lateral flagella.

Ochrobactrum species are strongly trypsin and pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase positive and are saccharolytic, with rapid acidification of glucose and xylose. Acidification of mannitol is irregular and often delayed positive. Ethylene glycol is acidified. Urease is positive in most species; phenylalanine deaminase is always positive. Nitrate reduction and nitrite reduction are positive, except in O. haematophilum. O. intermedium can be distinguished from O. anthropi by colistin resistance and growth at 41°C. Urease is often negative or delayed in this species. O. pseudintermedium is the only species growing at 45°C. Resistance to colistin, tetracycline, and aminoglycosides may have diagnostic value for distinction between O. intermedium and O. pseudintermedium. Among aminoglycosides, netilmicin provides the most clear-cut results. Comparative phylogenomics of the family Brucellaceae reveals a path to virulence (215).

O. anthropi has been isolated from various environmental and human sources, predominantly from patients with catheter-related bacteremia (211, 216), bloodstream infections, and a few other infections (case reports of neonatal sepsis, pneumonia, osteomyelitis, and endocarditis) (217–221). One hospital outbreak in transplant patients has been described (222). A few cases of O. intermedium infections have been reported (see, e.g., reference 223), but because of the close phenotypic similarity of O. anthropi and O. intermedium, it is possible that certain infections considered to be caused by O. anthropi were actually caused by O. intermedium (224). A case report of an O. anthropi bacteremia in a pediatric patient with malignant tumor has been described (225). Several virulence factors have been detected in O. intermedium (226).

O. anthropi strains are usually resistant to β-lactams, such as broad-spectrum penicillins, broad-spectrum cephalosporins, aztreonam, and amoxicillin-clavulanate, but are usually susceptible to aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, imipenem, tetracycline, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (216).

sect2.title: Pannonibacter
sect2.para: The genusPannonibacter, member of the family Stappiaceae (Alphaproteobacteria), currently comprises three species, P. carbonis, P. phragmitetus, and P. indicus, an environmental species. P. phragmitetus has been shown to be identical to the strains formerly designated Achromobacter groups B and E (227). The species resembles most strongly Rhizobium radiobacter, but saccharolytic activity is somewhat weaker and not as extended. Unlike Rhizobium and Pseudochrobactrum, which all have a strong phenylalanine deaminase activity, P. phragmitetus does not produce phenylpyruvic acid from phenylalanine. Another easy and reliable differential test is the hydrolysis of tributyrin, which is positive within 30 min for P. phragmitetus, whereas R. radiobacter strains are only positive after several hours of overnight incubation or remain negative. Pseudochrobactrum species do not hydrolyze tributyrin. Moreover, P. phragmitetus grows at 41°C while R. radiobacter does not.
Cases of septicemia and a liver abcess due toP. phragmitetus have been reported (228, 229).

sect2.title: Pseudochrobactrum
sect2.para: The genusPseudochrobactrum was described in 2006 (230) and comprises six species, among them P. saccharolyticum and P. asaccharolyticum. The type strain of P. asaccharolyticum was isolated from a knee aspirate (230). Two more human strains were isolated from Belgian clinical samples: a wound and an eye swab. P. asaccharolyticum slowly acidifies glucose and xylose, while P. saccharolyticum is more saccharolytic. Both species are susceptible to desferrioxamine and do not produce urease. Nitrate reduction and nitrite reduction are negative. The clinical significance of Pseudochrobactrum species remains to be assessed.

sect2.title: Rhizobium
sect2.para: The genusRhizobium harbours 84 species. Only R. radiobacter and Rhizobium pusense are clinically important (231).

Colonies ofR. radiobacter and R. pusense are circular, convex, smooth, and nonpigmented to light beige on SBA, with a diameter of 2 mm at 48 h. Colonies may appear wet and become extremely mucoid and pink on MacConkey agar with prolonged incubation. Cells measure 0.6 to 1.0 by 1.5 to 3.0 μm and occur singly and in pairs.

R. radiobacter grows optimally at 25 to 28°C and grows at 35°C as well, but not at 41°C. R. pusense is phenotypically very similar to R. radiobacter, but can be separated by the sequencing of the 16S rRNA and atpD genes (231).
R. radiobacter has broad saccharolytic activity, including mannitol and raffinose.

R. radiobacter (which may have also been falsely identified as R. pusense) has been most frequently isolated from blood, followed by peritoneal dialysate, urine, and ascitic fluid (232), and from cases of endocarditis (233) and keratitis (234). The species has also been isolated from the airways of patients with cystic fibrosis. The few cases are from patients with transcutaneous catheters or implanted biomedical prostheses, and effective treatment often requires removal of the device. Most strains are susceptible to broad-spectrum cephalosporins, carbapenems, tetracyclines, and gentamicin but not to tobramycin (232, 235). Testing of individual isolates is recommended for clinically significant cases.

sect2.title: Shewanella
sect2.para: The organisms formerly calledPseudomonas putrefaciens, Alteromonas putrefaciens, Achromobacter putrefaciens, and CDC group Ib have been placed in the genus Shewanella, which comprises more than 70 species. S. putrefaciens was described with two CDC biotypes. CDC biotype 1 was later described as S. putrefaciens sensu stricto, whereas CDC biotype 2 was subsequently assigned to a new species, S. alga (236), later corrected to S. algae.

Colonies ofShewanella species on SBA are convex, circular, smooth, and occasionally mucoid, produce a brown to tan soluble pigment, and cause green discoloration of the medium. Cells are long, short, or filamentous, reminiscent of Myroides. Motility is due to a single polar flagellum.

Most strains of bothS. putrefaciens and S. algae species produce H2S in KIA and TSI agar, a unique feature among clinically relevant GNF. Both are also ornithine decarboxylase positive and have strong alkaline phosphatase, strong trypsin, and strong pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase activities. S. algae is halophilic and asaccharolytic and requires NaCl for growth, with growth occurring on TSA plus 0.5% NaCl. S. putrefaciens does not require NaCl for growth and is saccharolytic, producing acid from maltose and sucrose and irregularly and weakly from glucose.

Khashe and Janda (237) have reported that S. algae is the predominant human clinical isolate (77%), while S. putrefaciens represents most non-human isolates (89%). Although infrequently isolated in the clinical laboratory, S. putrefaciens and S. algae have been recovered from a wide variety of clinical specimens and are associated with a broad range of human infections (238), including skin and soft tissue infections, otitis media, ocular infection, osteomyelitis, peritonitis, and septicemia. S. algae has been described as an emerging pathogen implicated in acute cholangitis (239). The habitat for S. algae is saline, whereas S. putrefaciens has been isolated mostly from fish, poultry, and meats as well as from freshwater and marine samples. A review on the clinical relevance of Shewanella algae has been published (240).

Shewanella species are generally susceptible to most antimicrobial agents effective against Gram-negative rods, except penicillin and cephalothin (166, 235). The mean MICs of S. algae for penicillin, ampicillin, and tetracycline are higher than the corresponding MICs of S. putrefaciens (237).

sect2.title: Sphingobacterium, Indole-Negative Species
sect2.para: In July 2022, a total of 65 species were described as belonging to the genusSphingobacterium. Based on 16S rRNA gene sequence data, the indole-producing Sphingobacterium mizutaii also belongs to this genus, and as a consequence, the description of the genus Sphingobacterium as indole negative was emended to indole variable (241). S. mizutaii is dealt with among the indole-positive GNF in Table 4.

The species of the genusSphingobacterium encountered in clinical samples include S. multivorum (formerly Flavobacterium multivorum and CDC group IIk-2), S. spiritivorum (including the species formerly designated as Flavobacterium spiritivorum, Flavobacterium yabuuchiae, and CDC group IIk-3), S. thalpophilum, S. hotanense, S. cellulitidis, and S. mizutaii (242, 243).

Colonies are yellowish.Sphingobacterium species are middle-sized, nonmotile, Gram-negative rods. All species are strongly saccharolytic; i.e., glucose, xylose, and other sugars are acidified. No acid is produced from mannitol, except by S. spiritivorum, which is also the only species to produce acid from ethylene glycol. S. thalpophilum can be distinguished from other Sphingobacterium species by its nitrate reductase and its growth at 41°C.

S. multivorum and S. spiritivorum can be distinguished from Sphingomonas paucimobilis (formerly CDC group IIk-1) because they are nonmotile, urease positive, and resistant to polymyxin. Many strains of other Sphingomonas species are also colistin resistant.

S. multivorum is the most common human species. It has been isolated from various clinical specimens, and the rare associations with serious infections (sepsis, peritonitis, end-stage renal disease, and necrotizing fasciitis) occurred usually in severely comorbid patients (244–247). Blood and urine have been the most common sources for the isolation of S. spiritivorum (248). S. thalpophilum has been recovered from wounds, blood, eyes, abscesses, and an abdominal incision (46). S. hotanense has been involved in a bacteremia case (247), and S. cellulitidis has been isolated from various clinical samples (249).

Sphingobacterium species are generally resistant to aminoglycosides and polymyxin B while susceptible in vitro to the quinolones and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Susceptibility to β-lactam antibiotics is variable, requiring testing of individual isolates (134).

sect2.title: Sphingomonas
sect2.para: The genusSphingomonas contains 146 species, of which only S. paucimobilis and S. parapaucimobilis are thought to be clinically important.

Sphingomonas colonies are slow growing on blood agar medium, with small colonies appearing after 24 h of incubation. Growth occurs at 37°C but not at 41°C, with optimum growth at 30°C. Almost all strains produce a yellow, insoluble pigment, different from flexirubin pigments, as can be established by the KOH test (2). Few strains are nonpigmented or develop a pale yellow color after several days. Older colonies demonstrate a deep yellow (mustard-color) pigment.

Sphingomonas species are medium to long, motile rods with a single polar flagellum. Motility occurs at 18 to 22°C but not at 37°C. However, few cells are actively motile in broth culture, thus making motility a difficult characteristic to demonstrate.

Oxidase is only weakly positive or even absent. All the strains are saccharolytic, but some acidify glucose only weakly and slowly. Urease is always negative, and nitrate reduction is only very rarely positive. Esculin is hydrolyzed, and β-galactosidase and alkaline phosphatase are positive. The yellow pigment of some strains may hamper a correct reading of the yellow color shift when nitrophenyl compounds of the latter substrates are used.
Members of this genus are known as decomposers of aromatic compounds and are being developed for use in bioremediation.Sphingomonas species are widely distributed in the environment, including water.

S. paucimobilis has been isolated from a variety of clinical specimens, including blood, CSF, peritoneal fluid, urine, wounds, and vaginal and cervix swabs, as well as from the hospital environment (250–254). S. parapaucimobilis clinical isolates have been obtained from sputum, urine, and the vagina (255). A peritonitis case has been reported associated with S. koreensis (256).

Most strains are resistant to colistin, but all are susceptible to vancomycin, which is exceptional for Gram-negative, nonfermenting rods. This is elsewhere only found inChryseobacterium and related genera like Elizabethkingia and Empedobacter. Most Sphingomonas strains are susceptible to tetracycline, chloramphenicol, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and aminoglycosides. Susceptibility to other antimicrobial agents, including fluoroquinolones, varies (166, 250).

sect1.title: Oxidase-Positive, Indole-Positive GNF
sect1.para: The natural habitats of most oxidase-positive, indole-positive GNF (Table 4) are soil, plants, and food and water sources, including those in hospitals. Clinically relevant species include Balneatrix alpica, Bergeyella zoohelcum, Chryseobacterium species, Elizabethkingia meningoseptica, Elizabethkingia anopheles, Elizabethkingia miricola, Empedobacter brevis, Empedobacter falsenii (formerly Wautersiella falsenii), Sphingobacterium mizutaii, and Weeksella virosa. All are indole, trypsin, pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase, and alkaline phosphatase positive, except for B. zoohelcum, which is pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase negative, and B. alpica, which is both trypsin and pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase negative. Table 4 presents an overview of the characteristics useful to differentiate among these species. It should be noted that phenotypic differentiation between these species is difficult and requires strict adherence to the described methods and the conditions under which they are performed. These methods and conditions have been thoroughly reviewed previously (2, 257, 258). Differentiation in the clinical microbiology laboratory is based on a limited number of phenotypic tests. Commercial identification kits are still often in use for differentiation, but discrepancies between the different commercial and conventional tests have been reported (258–261). Most commercial identification systems include Elizabethkingia meningoseptica in their analytical profile index, but this identification may be assigned to any of the Elizabethkingia species. Various molecular typing methods have shown to be more suitable for distinguishing these species, especially among the Chryseobacterium and Elizabethkingia species.

sect1.title: Balneatrix alpica
sect1.para: The genusBalneatrix accommodates only one species, B. alpica, which produces convex and smooth colonies of 2 to 3 mm in diameter. The center of the colonies is pale yellow after 2 to 3 days and pale brown after 4 days. B. alpica is a straight or curved, Gram-negative rod. It is the only motile species among the clinically relevant indole-positive GNF. Cells have one or two polar flagella.

The species is strictly aerobic and saccharolytic. Both trypsin and pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase are negative, unlike other indole-positive GNF. Growth occurs at 20 to 46°C on common media such as TSA but not on MacConkey agar.B. alpica acidifies fructose, glucose, glycerol, inositol, maltose, mannitol, mannose, sorbitol, and xylose. B. alpica is nitrate reductase and weakly gelatinase positive. It is similar to E. meningoseptica but can be differentiated from this species by its motility and nitrate reductase and by the absence of β-galactosidase.
