B. alpica was first isolated in 1987 during an outbreak of pneumonia and meningitis among persons who attended a hot (37°C) spring spa in southern France (262). Isolates from eight patients were recovered from blood, CSF, and sputum, and one was recovered from water. This species is only rarely isolated from human clinical specimens. Only one other report, on amoeba-associated microorganisms in intensive care unit pneumonia patients, has documented occurrence of this species (263).

sect2.title: Bergeyella
sect2.para: The genusBergeyella currently includes two species with validated names, Bergeyella porcorum (264) and B. zoohelcum. B. zoohelcum comprises former CDC group IIj strains (265). B. zoohelcum and Weeksella virosa are morphologically and biochemically similar organisms with cells measuring 0.6 by 2 to 3 μm, with parallel sides and rounded ends. B. zoohelcum colonies are sticky and tan to yellow.

BothB. zoohelcum and W. virosa fail to grow on MacConkey agar and are nonsaccharolytic. B. zoohelcum can be differentiated from W. virosa because it is pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase negative, strongly urease positive, and resistant to colistin.

B. zoohelcum is isolated mainly from wounds caused by animal (mostly dog) bites and can lead to meningitis, septicemia, and bacteremia (265–268). At present no specific antibiotic treatment is recommended, and antimicrobial susceptibility testing should be performed on significant clinical isolates. Harsent et al. (269) found significant multidrug resistances in isolates of this species. An additional species, “B. cardium” associated with infective endocarditis, has been proposed by Sohn et al. (270) and Guo et al. (271), and Mulliken et al. (272) found similar isolates to this species also associated with infectious endocarditis. A whole-genome sequence of an isolate of this species has been published by Pan et al. (273). The taxonomic status and clinical importance of this species remain unclear.

sect2.title: Chryseobacterium
sect2.para: The genusChryseobacterium now harbors more than 100 species, including the former CDC group IIb comprising Chryseobacterium indologenes, Chryseobacterium gleum, and others which represent still unnamed taxa.

Strains included in CDC group IIb are nonmotile rods. Cells ofC. indologenes are phenotypically similar to those of Chryseobacterium anthropi, Chryseobacterium hominis, E. meningoseptica, and S. mizutaii, i.e., they are thinner in their central than in their peripheral portions and include filamentous forms. CDC group IIb strains are oxidase and catalase positive, produce flexirubin pigments (2), are moderately saccharolytic, and are esculin and gelatin hydrolysis positive. C. indologenes and C. gleum can be differentiated from each other by four characteristics: C. indologenes displays a broad beta-hemolysis area within 3 days of incubation at 37°C on SBA, is always arabinose negative, does not acidify ethylene glycol, and does not grow at 41°C. C. gleum exhibits pronounced alpha-hemolysis, resembling viridans discoloration, always acidifies ethylene glycol, is arabinose positive or delayed positive, and grows at 41°C.

Beta-hemolysis is absent or very rare in other strains of CDC group IIb and is therefore almost specific for the identification ofC. indologenes, while the profile of C. gleum may be shared by other strains of this group. It should be noted that some C. indologenes strains do not produce flexirubin. It should again be noted here that phenotypic differentiation of species within that genus, but also from Elizabethkingia species, is difficult and requires strict adherence to the described methods and the conditions under which they are performed.

There are twoChryseobacterium species of major clinical interest, i.e., C. indologenes and C. gleum. Among CDC group IIb species, C. indologenes is usually considered most frequently isolated from clinical samples. C. indologenes has been reported with some 10 cases of ventilator-associated pneumonia (e.g., references 274–277). Other health care-related infections due to C. indologenes have been linked to the use of catheters during hospital stays (278–283). Also, C. indologenes has been identified as the cause of neonatal meningitis (284, 285). The full genome sequence of a multidrug-resistant strain isolated from a cystic fibrosis patient (286) and of a multidrug-resistant strain isolated from a wound (287) reveals the potential for this organism to become an emerging antibiotic-resistant pathogen (286).
C. indologenes is difficult to distinguish from related organisms by using routine methods. The production of novel types of metallo-β-lactamases from C. indologenes has been studied in detail (288).

Before the year 2006, three reports summarized most of the published cases of bacteremia and other infections caused byC. indologenes (282, 288) or unidentified group IIb Flavobacterium (289–292). Since 2006, C. indologenes has been described as an emerging pathogen (293, 294), and Mirza et al. (2017) (295) recently discovered that cystic fibrosis was the underlying disease for 80% of the Chryseobacterium and Elizabethkingia isolates from a pediatric hospital over a 4-year period.

Two retrospective reviews of 10 patients and 215 patients, respectively, withC. indologenes bacteremia acquired in the intensive care unit over a 4-year and 7-year period found that most patients had received more than 14 days of broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment prior to bacteremia onset, most infections were polymicrobial, and the primary site of infection could not be identified in many cases (267, 296). Many of these infections were polymicrobial, characterized by a coinfection with A. baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or Klebsiella pneumoniae. These findings supported the view that Chryseobacterium spp. is involved in the formation of a polymicrobial biofilm and that secreting β-lactamases may indirectly facilitate the coinfecting pathogens, in a manner similar to Stenotrophomonas maltophilia (297). This is supported by the finding that biofilm production allows Chryseobacterium spp. to directly cause bacteremia, as suggested by a study of 34 patient isolates, where 80% (4 out of 5) of isolates from blood were involved in biofilm production (298).

The first neonatal respiratory infections caused byC. gleum were reported in reference 299. Since 2014, numerous C. gleum infections have been described from blood. Additional details are given by Hugo et al. (300).

Holmes and coworkers (301) reported the first C. gleum infections from the vagina, from catheters, and in various body fluids. The absence of infection reports attributed to C. gleum from 1984 to 2014 seems to be mainly due to the fact that automated identification systems dominating the market during that time period did not include this species in their databases. A study from 2017 (302) compared identification with four automated systems for 22 isolates; these four systems identified correctly only 4 out of 22 isolates at the species level.

The vast majority of reportedChryseobacterium infections were detected in people with underlying comorbidities, on ventilators, or with indwelling devices such as arterial and central venous catheters, endotracheal tubes, and drains; among them, elderly patients and neonates are the most challenging cases. Some more details on the literature are given by Hugo et al. (300).
There are also reports on sepsis (303), soft tissue infection (304), or bacteremia (305) in healty individuals with no obvious exposure to health care environments.

Some additionalChryseobacterium species that have been isolated from human clinical samples include “Candidatus C. massiliae,” “Candidatus C. timonae,” C. anthropi, C. nakagawai, C. bernardetii, C. hominis, C. taklimakanense, C. treverense, and C. oranimense. Their pathogenicity to humans has not been proven until now. The absence of these species from identification systems suggests that they are likely undetected (300).

C. anthropi represents part of the strains formerly designated as CDC group IIe (306). Most strains display very sticky colonies, which are nonpigmented but may develop a slightly salmon-pinkish, rarely yellowish color after a few days. In contrast to C. hominis, the species is negative for esculin hydrolysis and acidification of ethylene glycol. In addition, many strains are susceptible to desferrioxamine. Most clinical isolates used for the description of C. anthropi were from wounds and blood cultures (306).

C. hominis includes the strains formerly included in CDC group IIc and most of the strains of CDC group IIh (307). This species does not produce flexirubin pigments, but some strains exhibit a slightly yellowish pigmentation. Colonies are often mucoid. C. hominis can be differentiated from C. gleum by the absence of flexirubin pigments and the lack of acid production from arabinose. C. indologenes strains lacking flexirubin pigments may resemble C. hominis, but the latter is never beta-hemolytic and always acidifies ethylene glycol. Many strains of C. hominis have been isolated from blood. Others have been isolated from dialysis fluid, pus, the eye, infraorbital drain, and aortic valve, but their clinical significance remains to be assessed (307).

Chryseobacterium treverense includes some of the strains formerly designated as CDC group IIe (308). Although described as indole negative, C. treverense strains produce indole that should be detected using the method recommended for GNF (see chapter 32 of this Manual). The species is phenotypically related to C. anthropi and C. hominis but can be distinguished by a negative (or very weak) gelatin hydrolysis and the absence of acetate alkalinization.

It is apparent that this group of organisms is intrinsically resistant to many antibiotics, including polymyxins, aminoglycosides (gentamicin, streptomycin, kanamycin), chloramphenicol, and most β-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems). A detailed report on this is given by Hugo et al. (300). The discussion of antibiotic susceptibility among Chryseobacterium and closely related taxa is difficult, due to the absence of officially recognized species-specific clinical breakpoints (https://clsi.org/standards/products/microbiology/documents/m100; http://www.eucast.org/clinical_breakpoints/). In addition, the applied methods are essential for evaluating antibiotic susceptibility of a specific Chyrseobacterium isolate. Broth and agar dilution methods seem to give reliable results, but disk diffusion and Etest assays are not reliable (309–311).

Chryseobacterium indologenes and C. gleum have, like Elizabethkingia meningoseptica, been found to produce carbapenem-hydrolyzing β-lactamases (312–314), which means that they are resistant to extended-spectrum cephalosporins and carbapenems, but not necessarily to ureidopenicillins, i.e., piperacillin. Many strains of the genus Chryseobacterium have also been found to be resistant to tetracyclines, erythromycin, and linezolid. Data on susceptibility to clindamycin, vancomycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole vary. Rifampin seems to be the most active antibiotic, in addition to the newer quinolones (gatifloxacin, levofloxacin, and sparfloxacin) (134, 309, 315).

Chen et al. (316) published a retrospective study of 215 patient isolates identified as belonging to the genus Chryseobacterium after colistin and tigecycline were given, and found that all isolates were resistant to colistin, aztreonam, gentamicin, and amikacin, and most were susceptible to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (94.9%), followed by cefoperazone-sulbactam (59%) (316). Two years later, Chang et al. reported results on 34 C. indologenes isolates (confirmed by 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis) and found that all isolates were resistant to gentamicin, amikacin, ceftriaxone, chloramphenicol, colistin, and imipenem, some were susceptible to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and ciprofloxacin, and all were susceptible to minocycline (298).
It is unfortunately quite common that patients withChryseobacterium infections are treated with an ineffective antibiotic. More details are given by Hugo et al. (300).

sect2.title: Elizabethkingia
sect2.para: Colonies ofE. meningoseptica, formerly Chryseobacterium meningosepticum (259), are smooth and large, either nonpigmented or producing a pale yellow or slightly salmon-pinkish pigment after 2 or 3 days. Characteristic features are acid production from mannitol and β-galactosidase activity. Gelatin and esculin hydrolysis are positive. Elizabethkingia and Chryseobacterium species can be differentiated as well on the basis of 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis (259, 306). Since the original description of E. meningoseptica (initially by Elizabeth King in 1959 as Flavobacterium meningosepticum, causing invasive neonatal and infant disease, notably meningitis) this species has been considered as the most important of clinical relevance. But after the discovery that E. anophelis is the major component of clinically derived strain collections (317–319), it seems to be clear that many case reports and outbreaks initially attributed to E. meningoseptica have been due instead to E. anophelis. Unfortunately, the phenotypes of both species are very similar; the majority of phenotypic typing kits used in clinical laboratories are unable to separate these two species and still report any infection by an Elizabethkingia species as being due to E. meningoseptica (318, 319)

E. meningoseptica has been reported to be associated with (neonatal) meningitis (320), health care-related outbreaks (see references 321, 322), different types of infection (e.g., adult pneumonia and septicemia (235, 323), and infections reported in dialysis units (324).

Infections withElizabethkingia species are rare. In an earlier study, von Graevenitz (235) estimated that about 120 cases of invasive neonatal disease had been reported in the literature by 1985, and later Bloch et al. found 308 patient reports in the English language literature up to 1994 of cultures positive for Elizabethkingia, of which about 60% were judged to represent true infections (321). Between the years 1994 and 2006, a total of 13 cases of neonatal infections were reported. Later, beween 2006 and 2018 a much larger total of 290 cases of infection caused by Elizabethkingia, and many additional individual cases, have been listed (details on the literature are given by Nicholson et al. [324]). From these increasing numbers, it seems to be obvious that Elizabethkingia may be regarded as an emerging pathogen (321, 325–327).

E. miricola, initially described as Chryseobacterium miricola by Li et al. (328), has been reported as the cause of sepsis (329) and urinary tract infection (330) and as an opportunistic oral pathogen in a patient with humoral immunodeficiency (331). In addition, this species, along with others of the “E. miricola cluster,” has been isolated from sputa, cough swabs, and tracheal aspirates of patients with cystic fibrosis (332) and has also been reported as the cause of exacerbation of pulmonary symptoms in a cystic fibrosis patient (332).

After the description ofE. anophelis in 2011 (333), many reports have been published revealing this organism to be an emerging pathogen, especially in immunocompromised patients. A first report of a meningitis case was published in 2013 (334). A transmission from mother to infant was reported in 2015, and a case of bacteremia with a high mortality was subsequently described (334). In the same year, an E. anophelis outbreak was reported and the complete genomes of some of the strains were sequenced (335). A global epidemiological study showed that distinct E. anophelis sublineages demonstrated high genetic relatedness between African isolates (325). E. anophelis was isolated from two separate patients with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome and lower respiratory tract infection (336). Janda and coworkers (337) concluded that, within a little more than 5 years since its taxonomic description in 2011, E. anophelis from the midgut of mosquitoes has emerged as an important cause of sepsis in adults and children and in cases of neonatal meningitis. At least three moderate- to large-scale outbreaks of disease have been caused by this bacterium, with the largest two occurring in the United States in 2015–2016. As a result, E. anophelis seems to be the predominant Elizabethkingia species found in blood cultures (317), and it is currently believed that many of the cases and outbreaks of E. meningoseptica reported in the literature were actually due to E. anophelis. More details on the pathogenicity of Elizabethkingia have been summarized by Nicholson et al. (338). Little is presently known regarding its epidemiology, modes of transmission, and pathogenicity factors (337).

The appropriate choice of effective antimicrobial agents for the treatment of chryseobacterial infections is difficult (322). Chryseobacterium species and E. meningoseptica are inherently resistant to many antimicrobial agents commonly used to treat infections caused by Gram-negative bacteria (aminoglycosides, β-lactam antibiotics, tetracyclines, and chloramphenicol) but are often susceptible to agents generally used for treating infections caused by Gram-positive bacteria (rifampin, clindamycin, erythromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and vancomycin) (134, 166, 235). Although early investigators recommended vancomycin for treating serious infection with E. meningoseptica, subsequent studies showed greater in vitro activity of minocycline, rifampin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and fluoroquinolones (134, 321). Among the quinolones, levofloxacin is more active than ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin (134). C. indologenes is reported to be uniformly resistant to cephalothin, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, aztreonam, aminoglycosides, erythromycin, clindamycin, vancomycin, and teicoplanin, while susceptibility to piperacillin, cefoperazone, ceftazidime, imipenem, quinolones, minocycline, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is variable, requiring testing of individual isolates (134). Several studies reported that administration of a fluoroquinolone, minocycline, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, or rifampin and treatment of local infection improve the clinical outcome of patients with E. meningoseptica infections. The choice of appropriate antimicrobial therapy is further complicated by the fact that MIC breakpoints for resistance and susceptibility of chryseobacteria have not been established by the CLSI, and the results of disk diffusion testing are unreliable in predicting antimicrobial susceptibility of Chryseobacterium species (339). The Etest is a possible alternative to the standard agar dilution method for testing cefotaxime, ceftazidime, amikacin, minocycline, ofloxacin, and ciprofloxacin, but not piperacillin (292). Definitive therapy for clinically significant isolates should be guided by individual susceptibility patterns determined by an MIC method.

sect2.title: Empedobacter
sect2.para: E. brevis (340) colonies are yellowish pigmented but do not produce flexirubin. E. brevis can be differentiated from C. indologenes, C. gleum, other CDC group IIb strains, and C. hominis by its lack of esculin hydrolysis. Growth on MacConkey agar and stronger gelatinase activity are useful to distinguish it from C. anthropi. The species is rarely recovered from clinical material (341, 342).

A second species of the genusEmpedobacter is Empedobacter falsenii (formerly Wautersiella falsenii) (343). E. falsenii is closely related to E. brevis, from which it differs by its urease activity. Two genomovars have been described (344): genomovar 1 is always esculin positive and β-galactosidase negative, whereas 90% of the genomovar 2 strains are esculin negative and 63% are β-galactosidase positive.

E. falsenii is more frequently isolated from clinical samples than E. brevis and was detected as causal agent of a respiratory tract infection in an immunocompromised man (345), in a sample from a cervical neck abscess (346), in a urine sample from an infant with pyelonephritis (347), and in a patient with cystic fibrosis (348). Genome sequence analyses of selected strains revealed extensive drug resistances, among them novel variants of metallo-β-lactamases (349–351).

sect2.title: Sphingobacterium
sect2.para: S. mizutaii, previously known as Flavobacterium mizutaii (243) but originally described as Sphingobacterium mizutae, is an indole-positive Sphingobacterium species of clinical importance. It is saccharolytic—producing acid from a large number of carbohydrates, including xylose—similar to other Sphingobacterium species, from which it can be distinguished by its indole production, its failure to grow on MacConkey agar, and its usual lack of urease activity (46).

S. mizutaii can be distinguished from Chryseobacterium and Empedobacter species by its lack of gelatin hydrolysis and of flexirubin production. S. mizutaii produces acid from xylose but not from ethylene glycol, allowing differentiation from other indole-positive species. The phenotypic profile of S. mizutaii is similar to that of the strains described as Chryseobacterium CDC group IIi. Furthermore, 16S rRNA gene sequencing confirms that most CDC group IIi strains actually belong to the species S. mizutaii (241). S. mizutaii has been isolated from blood, CSF, and wound specimens (46). A second species, Sphingobacterium cellulitidis, most closely related to S. mizutaii and showing a positive trytophan deaminase reaction, has been described as a cause of cellulitis infection (249).

sect2.title: Weeksella
sect2.para: W. virosa colonies are mucoid and adherent to the agar, reminiscent of the sticky colonies of B. zoohelcum. Colonies are not pigmented after 24 h of incubation but may become yellowish tan to brown after 2 or 3 days. The cellular morphology of W. virosa is dealt with above in the discussion of B. zoohelcum. W. virosa can be differentiated from B. zoohelcum because it is urease negative and polymyxin B and colistin susceptible, whereas B. zoohelcum is rapid urease positive and polymyxin B and colistin resistant. W. virosa comprises former CDC group IIf strains (352). W. virosa is isolated mainly from urine and vaginal samples (352) and has been reported in cases of postoperative intracranial infection, fatal sepsis, and peritonitis (353–355). In contrast, B. zoohelcum is isolated mostly from animal bites. An additional species, Weeksella massiliensis, isolated from a patient with acute cystitis, has been described by Sankar et al. (356), but no futher report has been published so far for this species.

sect1.title: Pink-Pigmented GNF
sect1.para: It should be noted that colonies ofC. anthropi and E. meningoseptica can be lightly salmon colored on some media after several days of incubation, but this is not to be confused with the clearly pink colonies of the taxa discussed here (Table 5).

sect2.title: Asaia
sect2.para: Asaia is a genus of the family Acetobacteraceae (Alphaproteobacteria) that includes eight species. The natural habitats of Asaia species are reported to be the flowers of the orchid tree, the plumbago plant, and fermented glutinous rice, all originating in hot tropical climates, particularly in Indonesia and Thailand.

entry.phrase: Roseomonas gilardii subsp. gilardii and Roseomonas gilardii subsp. rosea (5)

sect2.para: aNumbers in parentheses after organism names are numbers of strains tested. Values are percentages; those in parentheses represent delayed positivity. W, weakly positive reaction.
bONPG, o-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside.

Growth ofAsaia species is scant to moderate on SBA. Colonies are pale pink. In contrast to Methylobacterium, colonies are not dark under UV light. Asaia species are small to middle-sized, Gram-negative rods, usually motile by one or two polar or lateral flagella. The species are oxidase negative and strongly saccharolytic; i.e., glucose, mannitol, xylose, and L-arabinose are acidified very rapidly, often within 1 h on low-peptone phenol red agar. Acid is also produced from ethylene glycol. Furthermore, Asaia species are biochemically rather inert, except for benzyl arginine aminopeptidase (trypsin) activity. Asaia species can be distinguished from Methylobacterium species by cell morphology, a stronger saccharolytic activity, and acid production from mannitol.

A. bogorensis has been reported as a cause of peritonitis in a patient on automated peritoneal dialysis (357) and as a cause of bacteremia after intravenous drug abuse (358). A. lannensis has been identified as the cause of health care-related infections in pediatric patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (359) and of bacteremia in an intravenous-drug user (360).

Asaia species have been reported to be resistant to ceftazidime, meropenem, imipenem, trimethoprim, amikacin, vancomycin, aztreonam, penicillin, and ampicillin by disk diffusion (361). The A. bogorensis strain reported by Snyder et al. (357) was susceptible to aminoglycosides (amikacin, tobramycin, and gentamicin) and resistant to ceftazidime and meropenem by disk diffusion.

sect2.title: Azospirillum
sect2.para: Azospirillum is a genus of nitrogen-fixing plant symbionts that is in a different order of bacteria, i.e., the order Rhodospirillales (362). The genus contains 23 species. Some strains of this genus may occasionally be isolated from clinical material (363).

Colonies are pale pink and resemble those ofRoseomonas. Cells are somewhat more rod shaped than Roseomonas and are motile by one or two polar flagella. Oxidase is positive and hydrolysis of urea is strongly positive, as in Roseomonas species. β-Galactosidase activity and esculin hydrolysis allow differentiation of Azospirillum from other pink-pigmented species.

sect2.title: Methylobacterium
sect2.para: The genusMethylobacterium (family Methylobacteriaceae) consists of over 50 species. Methylobacterium species are isolated mostly from vegetation but may also occasionally be found in the hospital environment. M. mesophilicum (formerly Pseudomonas mesophilica, Pseudomonas extorquens, and Vibrio extorquens), M. extorquens, and M. zatmanii are the three most commonly isolated species from normally sterile body sites (blood, cerebrospinal fluid, bone marrow, synovia, and ascitic and peritoneal fluids) (364).

Colonies ofMethylobacterium species are small, dry, and coral pink. Under UV light, Methylobacterium colonies appear dark due to absorption of UV light (363). Growth is fastidious on ordinary media such as TSA, producing 1-mm-diameter colonies after 4 to 5 days on SBA, modified Thayer-Martin, buffered charcoal-yeast extract, and Middlebrook 7H11 agars, with the best growth occurring on Sabouraud agar and usually no growth on MacConkey agar. Optimum growth occurs between 25 and 30°C. They are able to utilize methanol as a sole source of carbon and energy, although this characteristic may be lost on subculture. Cells are pleomorphic, vacuolated rods that stain poorly and may resist decolorization (Fig. 4). Motility by one polar flagellum is difficult to demonstrate. In the description of the genus (365), methylobacteria were reported to be oxidase positive, but the strains tested by Georges Wauters with the dimethyl-paraphenylenediamine reagent were all oxidase negative (see chapter 45 of the previous edition of this Manual). Saccharolytic activity is weaker than in Asaia spp., no acid is produced from mannitol, and acid is produced irregularly from glucose. Arabinose, xylose, and ethylene glycol are acidified. Urea and starch are hydrolyzed.

Although in general,Methylobacterium species cause mild clinical symptoms as opportunistic pathogens in immunocompromised patients, they have been reported to cause septicemia, continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis-related peritonitis, skin ulcers, synovitis, brain abscesses, and other infections, often in immunocompromised patients (366–371). Their ability to form biofilms and to resist high temperatures, drying, and disinfecting agents probably contributes to their colonization of hospital environments, e.g., endosocpes (364). Tap water has been implicated as a possible agent of transmission in hospital environments, and methods for monitoring water systems for methylobacteria have been described previously (3).

Active drugs include aminoglycosides and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, whereas β-lactam drugs show variable activity (372). These species are best tested for susceptibility by agar or broth dilution at 30°C for 48 h (30).

figure.title: FIGURE 4 Gram stain of Methylobacterium, showing pleomorphic, Gram-negative rods with vacuoles.

sect2.title: Roseomonas
sect2.para: As of July 2022, the genusRoseomonas includes 50 species, and the type species, R. gilardii, comprises the subspecies R. gilardii subsp. rosea and R. gilardii subsp. gilardii (362).
The followingRoseomonas species can be isolated from clinical samples: R. gilardii subsp. gilardii, R. gilardii subsp. rosea, R. mucosa, and R. cervicalis.

Colonies are mucoid and runny and grow larger than those ofAsaia and Methylobacterium. Pigmentation varies from pale pink to coral pink. Roseomonas cells are nonvacuolated, coccoid, plump rods, mostly in pairs and short chains (Fig. 5) and usually motile by one or two polar flagella, but motility is often difficult to demonstrate. Growth occurs at 37°C on ordinary media like SBA, and mostly on MacConkey agar, but the best growth is observed on Sabouraud agar. Oxidase is dependent on the species and often weak. Saccharolytic activity is also species dependent. All Roseomonas species strongly hydrolyze urea but not esculin. They are trypsin and β-galactosidase negative. Phenotypic distinction among the different species is based on oxidase, acid production from carbohydrates, and pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase and nitrate reductase activities.

R. mucosa rapidly acidifies arabinose, mannitol, and fructose. Glucose is acidified within 1 to 3 days. Oxidase is negative, and pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase is positive. R. gilardii subsp. gilardii and R. gilardii subsp. rosea exhibit a weak oxidase reaction and are pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase positive. The two subspecies cannot be differentiated by current phenotypic tests. They are less saccharolytic than R. mucosa and produce acid from arabinose and fructose, but only irregularly and slowly from mannitol and rarely from glucose. R. cervicalis is strongly oxidase positive but has no pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase activity. Only arabinose and fructose are positive within 2 days and xylose within 3 or 4 days. The single strain of genomic species 4 examined is also oxidase positive and pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase negative, and its saccharolytic activity is limited to acid production from glucose and fructose. It is the only species displaying nitrate reduction. Genomic species 5 is weakly oxidase positive and pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase negative. It is the least saccharolytic species, with only a delayed acid production from fructose. Ethylene glycol is acidified by all species except by genomic species 4 and 5.

Roseomonas species are uncommon isolates from humans, but they are nevertheless the most frequently isolated pink GNF. Clinical isolates have been recovered from blood, wounds, exudates, abscesses, genitourinary sites, continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis fluid, and bone (373–377). A total of 35 cases of opportunistic infections with Roseomonas species have been reviewed (199). In multiple-case reports, about 60% of the isolates recovered have been from blood, with about 20% from wounds, exudates, and abscesses and about 10% from genitourinary sites (373, 375).

figure.title: FIGURE 5 Gram stain of Roseomonas, showing Gram-negative, coccoid organisms.

sect2.para: Dé et al. (373) summarized susceptibility data from three published reports on a combined 80 strains of Roseomonas. All strains were susceptible to amikacin (100%); frequently susceptible to imipenem (99%), ciprofloxacin (90%), and ticarcillin (83%); less susceptible to ceftriaxone (38%), trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (30%), and ampicillin (13%); and rarely susceptible to ceftazidime (5%). All strains were resistant to cefepime. In catheter-related infections, eradication of the organism has proven difficult unless the infected catheter is removed.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Decisions about performing susceptibility testing are complicated by the fact that the CLSI interpretive guidelines for disk diffusion testing of GNF are limited toPseudomonas species, B. cepacia, Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, and Acinetobacter species and therefore, except for Acinetobacter species, do not include the organisms covered in this chapter. Furthermore, results obtained with Acinetobacter species, for example by using disk diffusion, do not correlate with results obtained by conventional MIC methods. In general, laboratories should try to avoid performing disk diffusion-based susceptibility testing on the organisms included in this chapter. When clinical necessity dictates that susceptibility testing be performed, an overnight MIC method, e.g., Etest (bioMérieux) on Mueller-Hinton agar (291), is recommended.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Although certain GNF can, on occasion, be frank pathogens, e.g.,Burkholderia pseudomallei, E. meningoseptica, and P. aeruginosa, they are generally considered to be of low virulence and often occur in mixed infections, making it difficult to determine when to work up cultures and when to perform susceptibility studies. E. meningoseptica in neonatal meningitis, M. lacunata in eye infections, and B. catarrhalis in respiratory tract infections should be reported as significant pathogens. Direct Gram stain interpretation of clinical specimens may be of limited importance because these organisms often occur in mixed infections and because their clinical importance has to be interpreted taking into account the considerations discussed below. Decisions regarding the significance of GNF in a clinical specimen must consider the clinical condition of the patient and the source of the specimen submitted for culture. In general, the recovery of a GNF in pure culture from a normally sterile site warrants identification and susceptibility testing, whereas predominant growth of a GNF from a nonsterile specimen, such as an endotracheal culture from a patient with no clinical signs or symptoms of pneumonia, would not be worked up further. Identification of GNF may also be important to document health care-related outbreaks linked to hospital environments or medical devices. Because many GNF exhibit multiple antibiotic resistance, patients who are on antibiotics often become colonized with GNF. GNF species isolated in mixed cultures can usually be reported by descriptive identification, e.g., “growth of P. aeruginosa and two varieties of GNF not further identified.”
